message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Listeria monocytogenes is sensitive to ampicillin, making it the best choice for treatment. Ceftriaxone is used for bacterial meningitis but not for Listeria monocytogenes. Chloramphenicol is another option, but ampicillin is the preferred first-line agent. Vancomycin is not effective against Listeria monocytogenes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Listeria monocytogenes is susceptible to Ampicillin, as well as other antibiotics such as penicillin and trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. Chloramphenicol also has activity against Listeria, but it may be associated with aplastic anemia. Ceftriaxone and Vancomycin are not effective against Listeria.

Chloramphenicol is also effective but is reserved for severe infections or when other antibiotics fail. Vancomycin is not effective against Listeria monocytogenes.

Chloramphenicol can also be used, but due to its risk of aplastic anemia, it’s not the first choice. Ceftriaxone and vancomycin are not effective against Listeria monocytogenes.

Chloramphenicol is also effective but has higher toxicity risk, while ceftriaxone and vancomycin are not effective against Listeria monocytogenes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Listeria monocytogenes is a gram-positive bacterium and is treated with ampicillin as it is sensitive to it. Vancomycin is used for gram-positive infections, but it has poor activity against Listeria monocytogenes. Ceftriaxone and Chloramphenicol are not typically used to treat Listeria infections.

Chloramphenicol can also be used, but it has more adverse effects than Ampicillin. Ceftriaxone is not effective against Listeria monocytogenes, and Vancomycin is not the drug of choice for this type of infection.
